headline.main: Q. and A. with a Pet Nutritionist

docs.abstract: A pet nutritionist answers readers' questions.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Joe - Joseph J. Wakshlag - a clinical nutritionist at the Baker Institute for Animal Health at Cornell University, is answering readers' questions about pet food. He is no longer taking questions.
docs.snippet: A pet nutritionist answers readers' questions.

headline.main: Provide Cash, or Benefits in Kind?

docs.abstract: Economists agree that it's most efficient to deliver benefits to the needy in the form of cash, but most public policies do otherwise, an economist writes.
docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.
docs.snippet: Economists agree that it's most efficient to deliver benefits to the needy in the form of cash, but most public policies do otherwise, an economist writes.

headline.sub: A 5-Year Plan to Reduce Fats, Sugars and Salt in Food;
headline.seo: Wal-Mart Plans to Make Its House Brand Healthier
headline.main: Wal-Mart Shifts Strategy to Promote Healthy Foods

byline.contributor: William Neuman contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: The company said it would lower the price of fresh produce and cut sugar, fat and salt in its house brands, and would press other food manufacturers to do the same.
docs.snippet: The company said it would lower the price of fresh produce and cut sugar, fat and salt in its house brands, and would press other food manufacturers to do the same.

headline.main: The Pros and Cons of Genetic Data: Debating Personal DNA Testing

byline.original: By JENNIFER CUTRARO and HOLLY EPSTEIN OJALVO

docs.abstract: Lesson Plan | Debating the medical and ethical issues of personal DNA testing.
docs.lead_paragraph: Overview | What is personal DNA testing and how does it work? Why are some doctors and health professionals concerned over the growing availability of these tests for consumers? In this lesson, students review current technologies for DNA testing. They explore the reliability of these tests and debate the medical and ethical issues surrounding personal genetic testing.
docs.snippet: Lesson Plan | Debating the medical and ethical issues of personal DNA testing.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEN, MELVIN R.

docs.lead_paragraph: SEIDEN--Melvin R.,age 80, died of a massive brain hemorrhage on January 14, 2011. The eldest son of Katherine and Murray Seiden, Mel attended schools in New Jersey and graduated from Harvard College (1952) and Harvard Law School (1955). He served in the Navy from 1955-1958 and retired as a Lieutenant. Mel was inspired by the life of Paul J. Sachs who, after a successful career at Goldman Sachs, became an associate director of the Fogg Art Museum at Harvard. Mel started in the investment field at Loeb Rhoades & Co. (1958-1961), then founded Seiden & deCuevas (1962-1986). He was chairman of several venture capital funds in the 1970's. Mel was also a trustee of various Merrill Lynch mutual funds and investment companies from 1981-2002, and he was most recently a consultant and director of Edge Management. After retiring from active work in the financial field, he devoted himself to art and philanthropy. As he was colorblind, he developed a special interest in drawings, cartoons (New Yorker) and caricatures (Al Hirschfeld) and most recently illuminated medieval manuscripts, all of which he collected on behalf of institutions. His philanthropic activities were centered at Harvard, including Villa I Tatti, The School of Public Health and various art museums and libraries. He also derived enormous pleasure, and made great friends, at the Fidelity Charitable Gift Fund in Boston where he was a trustee from 2004-2010. His New York philanthropies were centered at The Morgan Library, where he was on several visiting committees; The Frick Collection, where he was a trustee; and The Childrens' Aid Society, where he was also a trustee and helped develop programs to counter obesity and teenage pregnancy. He supported art by financing catalogues and exhibitions around the globe from The Shanghai Art Museum, The Ambrosiana in Milan, the Museums of Scotland, The Albertina in Vienna, British libraries and museums. Mel had an iconoclastic turn of mind, an astonishing memory and delightful wit. He was kind and thoughtful in conversation and a wonderful companion, friend and mentor. In addition to legions of friends, he leaves his wife, Janine Luke, three sisters, numerous nieces and nephews and his devoted associates, Bea Pappagallo and Chiquita Harding, all of whom colored his life and provided love and fun. There will be a Memorial Service at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to any of the New York charities listed below would be appreciated: The Childrens' Aid Society, Attn: Richard R. Buery, Jr., 105 East 22nd St., New York, NY 10010; The Frick Collection, Attn: Anne Poulet, 1 East 70th St, New York, NY 10016; The Morgan Library, Attn: William M. Griswold, 225 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10016.

headline.seo: Trials in a Vacuum: Study of Studies Shows Few Citations
headline.print_headline: Trial in a Vacuum: Study of Studies Shows Few Citations
headline.main: Trial in a Vacuum: Study of Studies Shows Few Citations

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of studies showed that nearly half of clinical trials cite none or only one of previous trials addressing the same question.
docs.snippet: A study of studies showed that nearly half of clinical trials cite none or only one of previous trials addressing the same question.

headline.seo: Personal DNA Tests Deliver Predictions With Few Side Effects
headline.print_headline: Heavy Doses of DNA Data, With Few Side Effects
headline.main: Heavy Doses of DNA Data, With Few Side Effects

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people say they’ll pay for genetic tests even if the predictions are sometimes wrong, and most people don’t seem to be traumatized even when they receive bad news.
docs.snippet: Most people say they’ll pay for genetic tests even if the predictions are sometimes wrong, and most people don’t seem to be traumatized even when they receive bad news.

headline.seo: Mediterranean Diet May Slow Cognitive Decline, Study Says
headline.print_headline: AGING: The Mediterranean Diet as Brain Food
headline.main: Aging: Mediterranean Diet as Brain Food

docs.lead_paragraph: The Mediterranean diet — heavy on vegetables, fish and olive oil, with moderate amounts of wine — may be associated with slower rates of mental decline in the elderly.
docs.snippet: The Mediterranean diet — heavy on vegetables, fish and olive oil, with moderate amounts of wine — may be associated with slower rates of mental decline in the elderly.
